2. The transmission in manuscript.

a. The Cod. pal. vindobonensis 1294 (A).

With the exception of a fragment, of which more will be said hereafter, no copy of Wyclif’s treatise on the Church has been preserved in England. On the other hand, a Codex exists on the Con- tinent, which was undoubtedly transcribed at Oxford, at the Whit— suntide of 1407, by a Bohemian student, and revised with the help of another Bohemian student. This is the Cod. ¹294 of the Imperial Library of Vienna.

This Codex contains on 251 parchment leaves, large octavo (24¹l2cm >< 151s2cm)3 I. fol. 1³—127a Wyclif’s tract “De veritate sacrae scripturae''; II. fol. ¹2ga-210b the tract “De sancta matre ecclesia''‚ and ΙΙΙ. fol. 2¹2³—251b the tract “De dominio divino‘’. The two latter are likewise by Wyclif.

Each of the 251 leaves of the Codex contains 4 columns (a, b, c, d): and each column contains about 40 lines. The paging does not include two blank leaves at the beginning, and one at the end.

Both the copyist and the corrector of this MS. were Bohemians, as is evident from several Czechian glosseS. A note at the end of the tract “De veritate sacrae scripturae'' (fol. 119⁶) gives both their names: “Correctus graviter anno domini 1407 in vigilia Purificacionis sancte Marie Oxon(ii) per Nicolaum Faulfiss et Georgium de Knyehnicz.'’

The tradition of later ages has assigned to Nicolaus Faulfisch the distinction of having been the first to introduce the theologica} writings of Wyclif into Bohemia. The impossibility of this will however be seen, when we remember that Wycliffite doctrines had been formally condemned at Prague, four years earlier than 1407.
